data.context: Delaware’s anti-takeover law provides that an “interested stockholder,” defined as a person who owns 15% or more of the outstanding voting stock of a corporation or a person who is an associate or affiliate of the corporation and, within the preceding three-year period, owned 15% or more of the outstanding voting stock, may not engage in specified business combinations with the corporation for a period of three years after the date on which the person became an interested stockholder.

qas.question: How does Delaware law define an "interested stockholder"?

answers.text: a person who owns 15% or more of the outstanding voting stock of a corporation or a person who is an associate or affiliate of the corporation and, within the preceding three-year period, owned 15% or more of the outstanding voting stock

data.context:
Amortization of Production Costs
As described in Note 2 and 7 to the consolidated financial statements and disclosed by management, capitalized film and television
production costs are amortized based on whether the content is predominantly monetized individually or as a group.

qas.question: According to what notes are capitalized film and television production costs amortized?

answers.text: Note 2 and 7

data.context: Production costs for content that is predominantly monetized individually is amortized based upon the ratio of the current period’s revenues to the estimated remaining total revenues (Ultimate Revenues).

qas.question: How are production costs for content predominantly monetized individually amortized?

answers.text: based upon the ratio of the current period’s revenues to the estimated remaining total revenues (Ultimate Revenues)

data.context: For film productions, Ultimate Revenues include revenues from all sources, which may include imputed license fees for content that is used by the Company’s DTC streaming services, that will be earned within ten years from the date of the initial release for theatrical films.

qas.question: What do Ultimate Revenues for film productions include?

answers.text: revenues from all sources, which may include imputed license fees for content that is used by the Company’s DTC streaming services, that will be earned within ten years from the date of the initial release for theatrical films

data.context: For episodic television series that are classified as individual, Ultimate Revenues include revenues that will be earned within ten years, including imputed license fees for content that is used on our DTC streaming services, from delivery of the first episode, or if still in production, five years from delivery of the most recent episode, if later.

qas.question: What do Ultimate Revenues for episodic television series include?

answers.text: revenues that will be earned within ten years, including imputed license fees for content that is used on our DTC streaming services, from delivery of the first episode, or if still in production, five years from delivery of the most recent episode, if later

data.context:
Production costs that are predominantly monetized as a group are amortized based on projected usage (which may be, for example, derived from historical viewership patterns), typically
resulting in an accelerated or straight-line amortization pattern.

answers.text:
based on projected usage (which may be, for example, derived from historical viewership patterns), typically
resulting in an accelerated or straight-line amortization pattern

data.context: The Company recognizes content assets (licensed and produced) as “Content assets, net” on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

qas.question: Where does the Company recognize content assets on its financial statements?

answers.text: As “Content assets, net” on the Consolidated Balance Sheets

data.context: For licensed content, the Company capitalizes the fee per title and records a corresponding liability at the gross amount of the liability when the license period begins, the cost of the title is known and the title is accepted and available for streaming.

qas.question: When does Netflix capitalize the fee for licensed content?

answers.text: when the license period begins, the cost of the title is known and the title is accepted and available for streaming

data.context: For produced content, the Company capitalizes costs associated with the production, including development costs, direct costs and production overhead. Participations and residuals are expensed in line with the amortization of production costs.

qas.question: What costs does Netflix capitalize for produced content?

answers.text: costs associated with the production, including development costs, direct costs and production overhead

data.context: Payments for content, including additions to content assets and the changes in related liabilities, are classified within "Net cash provided by (used in) operating activities" on the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.

qas.question: Where are payments for content classified on Netflix's financial statements?

answers.text: Within "Net cash provided by (used in) operating activities" on the Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows

data.context: Based on factors including historical and estimated viewing patterns, the Company amortizes the content assets (licensed and produced) in “Cost of revenues” on the Consolidated Statements of Operations over the shorter of each title's contractual window of availability or estimated period of use or ten years, beginning with the month of first availability.

qas.question: What does Netflix amortize content assets over?

answers.text: the shorter of each title's contractual window of availability or estimated period of use or ten years

data.context: The amortization is on an accelerated basis, as the Company typically expects more upfront viewing, and film amortization is more accelerated than TV series amortization.

qas.question: Is Netflix's content amortization on an accelerated basis?

answers.text: Yes

data.context: On average, over 90% of a licensed or produced content asset is expected to be amortized within four years after its month of first availability.

qas.question: What percentage of a content asset does Netflix expect to amortize within 4 years of availability?

answers.text: over 90%

data.context: The Company reviews factors impacting the amortization of the content assets on a regular basis.

qas.question: How often does Netflix review factors impacting content amortization?

answers.text: on a regular basis

data.context: The Company's estimates related to these factors require considerable management judgment.

qas.question: Do the estimates for content amortization factors require considerable management judgment?

answers.text: Yes

data.context: To date, the Company has not identified any such event or changes in circumstances. If such changes are identified in the future, these aggregated content assets will be stated at the lower of unamortized cost or fair value.

qas.question: Has Netflix identified events/changes requiring content assets to be stated at lower of cost or fair value?

answers.text: No

data.context: In addition, unamortized costs for assets that have been, or are expected to be, abandoned are written off.

data.context: Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method over the shorter of the estimated useful lives of the respective assets, generally up to 30 years, or the expected lease term for leasehold improvements, if applicable.

data.context: Deferred income taxes are recognized by applying enacted statutory tax rates applicable to future years to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases as well as net operating loss and tax credit carryforwards.

data.context: The Company translates the assets and liabilities of its non-U.S. dollar functional currency subsidiaries into U.S. dollars using exchange rates in effect at the end of each period.

data.context: Gains and losses from these translations are recognized in cumulative translation adjustment included in "Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)" in Stockholders’ equity on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

answers.text: in cumulative translation adjustment included in "Accumulated other comprehensive income (loss)" in Stockholders’ equity

data.context: The Company remeasures monetary assets and liabilities that are not denominated in the functional currency at exchange rates in effect at the end of each period.
